bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Austin Smith, November 5, 1952

div1.p: Hench suggests that Smith publish a short news item in "The Journal of the American Medical Association" about the upcoming dedication ceremony of Camp Lazear. He lists the names of Cuban officials involved in the project. Hench confesses his fear that the site will be called “Parque Finlay” instead of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Austin Smith, November 5, 1952
div1.opener:
November 5, 1952
Dr. Austin Smith, Editor
Journal of the American Medical Association
535 North Dearborn
Chicago, Illinois
My dear Doctor Smith:
div1.p:
I have long had as a hobby the conquest of yellow fever, the work of
Doctor Finlay of Havana and, more particularly, of Major Walter Reed
and his associates. I have made many visits to Havana and elsewhere
in pursuit of this hobby and one of the products of this investiga-
tion was the rediscovery in 1940 of the “lost” Camp Lazear where Reed
and his Associates did their work. Since then, I have enlisted the
help of Cubans and others to the end that Camp Lazear be memorialized
and at long last the Cuban Government is going to memorialize it on
December 3. As you undoubtedly know, there has been a rather seri-
monius debate in Cuba the last forty years by the proponents of Finlay
who insist that the Americans have not honored Finlay sufficiently and
that Reed was given all the credit. As a result, they have compounded
the error, have ignored Reed entirely and set up many memorials to
Finlay and so on.

This spring when I was in Havana and was shown the original blue prints
of the plans for the memorialization of Camp Lazear, I noted that the
camp was to be renamed “Parque Finlay” and Reed's Building No. 1 was
erroneously designated “Caseta de Finlay.” Dr. Pedro Nogueira is the
spark plug of the dedication. He is working as the agent of the
Minister of Health. I have known Doctor Nogueira for some years. He is
a very dynamic and fine young man. When I pointed out this error to him
he laughed and said that it would be corrected; that it was simply an
error by the draftsmen who of course do not know medical history. He
assured me that Reed's Building No. 1 will be properly named; however I
fear that the name Camp Lazear will not be perpetuated but will be re-
placed by “Parque Finlay.” The place is being graded and made into a
park, streets have been put in, a stone wall has been erected upon which
will be placed certain bronze medallions and plaques with the names of all
or most of the volunteers; bushes and other shrubbery have been planted and
Reed's Building No. 1 has been repaired.

Doctor Nogueira had hoped to have the dedication on November 20, the anni-
versary of the date the camp was originally opened but his superiors chose
December 3, Finlay's birthday and “Physicians' Day” in Cuba. That alone
Dr. Austin Smith
Page 2
November 5, 1952
may make for an overly strong “Finlay attitude” on the day of dedication.
I suppose that in order to get this project accomplished, I and other
Americans interested in the affair may have to accept the compromise of
“Parque Finlay” but none of us could possibly accept the false name of
Reed's Building No. 1. This summer I have had considerable correspondence
with Doctor Nogueira. He seems to want to be eminently fair and I must
have complete faith in him, but I do not know how far he can persuade his
superiors to approve his ideas which are in agreement with mine. The oc-
casion could be a fine one for an expression of Cuban-American friendship,
especially Cuban-American medical friendship and I hope indeed that no
erroneous naming will spoil the affair. However you will note from the
enclosure that the Havana newspapers have, accidentally or deliberately,
chosen to perpetuate the error and to call Reed's Building No. 1 “the
place where Doctor Finlay...”

I have been informed that certain Americans will be officially invited
to the dedication - the Surgeon General or his deputy, the American
Ambassador and others, myself included (I expect to fly down for the
ceremony.), but I do not believe any official invitations have yet been
sent out.

Doctor Smith, I am sure that this event will interest many American
physicians and deserves your attention. I suppose nothing more than a
short news item will be appropriate for the J.A.M.A. but I am sure that
you will want at least to have that. I am suggesting to you and to the
editors of the MILITARY SURGEON and the U. S. ARMED FORCES MEDICAL JOURNAL
that you contact the office of the Minister of Public Health and ask for
preliminary information regarding the dedication so that you can carry
the appropriate news item. You could write to Dr. Jose Raimundo Andreu,
El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social, Havana, or to the Public
Relations Department, El Ministerio de Salubridad y Asistencia Social.
Or you might prefer to write directly to Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219,
Marianao, Havana, Cuba, the dynamo behind the project. Your inquiry
would not only serve to show how much the Americans, especially the
American medical profession, appreciate this gracious gesture on the part
of the Cuban Government, but may definitely tend to keep them in line so
as to use the appropriate names and not try to put anything over. I must
hope and believe that they intend to do the right thing.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: Regarding the rediscovery of Camp Lazear, etc., please see the
enclosed reprint, pages 3 through 7.
